In the last 6 weeks I've created over 400+ individual pieces of content for clients for the upcoming holiday break. That's the copywriting, the sourcing of images (or graphic design if needed), the hashtag research, the approval process and the scheduling. And that 400+ pieces doesn't count the same content scheduled across multiple channels. üôÉ It's meant I've worked nights, weekends and way longer hours than I ever normally do, but it also means I get to enjoy the next 4-5 weeks off with my son and family. üòÑ I love working in social media, I love being a freelancer able to control my hours and my time off, and I also love the feeling of knowing I've done a bloody good job for my clients this year. But it's definitely hard work, especially at this time of the year. Social media is still a very underrated job, with many people considering it not a "real job" or "cruisy". My parents still really have no idea what I do for a job, just that I go online. üòÖ I bet a lot of other social media managers right now can 100% relate to this post, and I just want to say to them that you've done an amazing job. You've survived the crazy season and now it's time for a well-deserved break. I'm excited for 2024 as big things are coming for Sarah Lilly Media. A lot of changes are in the pipeline and I'm going to be able to focus on something that I've been wanting to do for a long time. Watch this space üòâ Happy holidays everyone! üå≤ #socialmediamarketing #socialmediamanager #freelancer #socialmedia #newzealand #contentcreator

Hey! sharing some simple and practical tips to keep your social media content interesting and creative: 1)Mix It Up: Don't post the same thing every day. Share a mix of pictures, videos, and text posts. 2)Have Theme Days: Pick a theme for each day of the week, like "Throwback Thursday" where you share old photos. 3)Tell Stories with Pictures: You can use pictures to show what your day or week looks like. People love a good story! 4)Ask Questions: Put up polls or ask questions. It's fun for people to share their opinions. 5)Share Funny Stuff: Everyone loves a good laugh. Share jokes, memes, or funny stories that fit your style. 6)Show What's Behind the Scenes: Share a peek behind the curtain. Show how things are made or what your workplace is like. 7)Run Contests: Have simple contests or giveaways. People love free stuff! 8)Share Tips and Tricks: Share something useful. It could be a life hack or a tip related to what you do. 9)Go Live: Use live videos. It's like talking to your friends in real-time. 10)Celebrate Milestones: Share when you achieve something or when it's your brand's birthday. 11)Use Emojis and Gifs: Emojis and gifs add fun to your posts. Use them to express yourself. 12)Learn from Others: Look at what others are doing. If something looks cool, try your own version. 13)Talk About Trends: Jump on trends or challenges. It keeps you current and relatable. 14)Share Personal Stories: Talk about your experiences. People like to connect with the human side of things. 15)Change It Up for Holidays: Share something special on holidays. It could be a festive picture or a holiday-themed message. 16)Ask for Input: Ask people for their opinions or ideas. It makes them feel involved. 17)Try New Platforms: Explore new social media apps. You might find a cool place where your audience hangs out. 18)Collaborate with Others: Partner with someone else. It could be a friend or another business. Two heads are often better than one. #contentcreation #marketing #agency #creativemarketing #trending #socialmediamarketing #collaboration #marketingdigital #digitalamarketing

*whew* üòÆüí® Recently I worked in the local political arena, and I learned way more than I could possibly fit into one post. AND I learned one incredibly valuable thing: Serving a client sometimes has to go beyond "give them what they want." I was previously used to having creative control over my brand's socials, albeit with time and budget constraints. I was used to bosses giving me the "press the magic Socials button to make us money" attitude. So when I offered to help a political candidate, I had that mindset and expected the work to change very little. What I forgot along the way was *who* I was working for. This client had certain needs as a marginalized person with intersecting identities, including disabilities, and along with that came a lack of face time on camera, a severe lack of production time, many accommodations, and an on-the-fly understanding of what they were and were not capable of doing. üå™ Whereas previously I had freedom to generate content and get annoyed when things didn't work out as planned, I needed to learn to pivot in an entirely new way that didn't involve merely my client changing their minds, or dishing new content or messaging ideas. The moment came when we *finally* had the opportunity to create a super fun socials contest of sorts. We mapped it out, and the kick-off content that I requested was a short video of my client saying one line that they could record on their own and send to me. We had a posting deadline by the end of a Friday. Unfortunately, their calendar filled up expeditiously, and they didn't have time to record the video. Instead they sent me one static pic. üòê Crestfallen, I spent an hour or so wracking my brain, trying to decide what to do with so little to work with. How could I kick off a great socials campaign with barely anything from the central figure of the narrative we'd built? Then it hit me! Take the original pic, edit it into four or five different crops, add music and text, and BAM! A classic tiktok video. This would seem obvious to some. To me, with little experience creating tiktoks for clients (time and budget), this was a major breakthrough. ‚õèÔ∏è Sometimes a client doesn't have the privilege to be "on" for content. Sometimes I need to check *my* privilege. Sometimes ya just gotta let go‚Äîlet go of your stunning idea and do what you can with what you have. By working with a marginalized person with specific needs, I learned how to re-work how *I* work. It was different from just coming up with something out of thin air; it was üí° generating something from practically nothing, üí° which I know plenty of marginalized people, including myself, have had to do time and time again IRL. Going forward, I will take into account my clients' needs as human beings, have contingency plans, and work harder to develop ideas that present quality content to the best of their and my abilities. ‚úî How have you learned to pivot your SM plans for a client?ü§î

Our teams pulled together 10 tips for social media content during the holiday period: üñäÔ∏è Pre-plan/ write your Jan/Feb content NOW so you can come back in 2024 ahead of the game ü§î Think about your audience‚Ä¶ what are they likely to be doing over the holiday period? Match your content to suit. üìà Is it time to amp up sales? Or back off for a break? üòÖ Keep your tone light. üôè Share gratitude often. It can be a tough time of the year for a lot of people so be kind. üéÑ Is a Christmas offer appropriate for your business? ‚¨áÔ∏è Think about reducing your number of posts for a few weeks during Christmas and New Year or even until your return to work date. üíî Remember your analytics may fluctuate more than usual over this time, don‚Äôt get disheartened. üì¢ Create an auto-response for your account inboxes so people know you're on limited duties and when you'll be available again to answer their message. üòé Take a break. Enforce a social media break for yourself over this period. As important as it is to communicate with your audience regularly, it is even more important to have a digital detox yourself. Give yourself permission to switch off. #socialmediamarketing #digitalmarketing #socialmediastrategy #socialmedia #contentstrategy #nzfarming #ruralsocialmedia #socialmedianz

I tried so hard for so long to create a formal content plan for myself on LinkedIn. I failed. So instead, my content planning looks like this. üëáüèΩ This is a literal screenshot of my ‚Äúcontent plan‚Äù for LinkedIn‚Äîan outline of what content I plan on posting and on what day. This is a note on my iPhone. üòÖ After about a week of content and little green check marks ‚úÖ, I delete the previous week‚Äôs line items and start to ideate on what the coming week should look like. It‚Äôs not sophisticated, and it‚Äôs not fancy. Heck, it‚Äôs not even aligned to a proper calendar that includes notifications for major holidays and world events‚Äîthings your regular content strategy without a doubt would take into consideration. It‚Äôs also not a month of scheduled content planned out in advance, because I tried that, and it simply did not work for me. By keeping about a week‚Äôs worth of a schedule jotted down at a time, I can see the flow of exciting events coming up that I want to feature; I can easily change a day‚Äôs content for another by quickly switching when I will post what; and I can get a little glimpse into what I‚Äôve been highlighting on LinkedIn, and then use it to reflect on whether I still have momentum with a given topic or instead need to switch it up and pivot to something else. I‚Äôm trying to post on LinkedIn once a day, every day, for as long as I can. I‚Äôve been at it for about a month. I truly don‚Äôt know why I‚Äôve decided to do this on LinkedIn and not on Instagram, but I trust my gut, and my gut tells me LinkedIn is the place I should be sharing more of this content. If you‚Äôve been thinking to yourself, ‚ÄúNicole has been posting a lot on LinkedIn lately,‚Äù you would be correct. I HAVE been posting a lot on LinkedIn lately. And this little screenshot‚Äîthis little note on my phone‚Äîis how I‚Äôve been organizing all of it. So that‚Äôs the tea. ü´ñ Sometimes it‚Äôs not about a super formal content plan or a really strategic outline. Sometimes it‚Äôs just about keeping the momentum, and taking it one day at a time. ‚òÄÔ∏è #linkedin #contentcreation #contentstrategy #contentplan #socialmedia #socialmediastrategy #socialmediamanagement #consistency #momentum #sharing #posting #iphone #notes #behindthescenes
